Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: RAPID: Maintain Mobility and Reduce Infection Through a Resilient Transit and Micromobility System

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration: The COVID-19 pandemic has caused unprecedented disruptions to health, the economy, and transportation systems in cities. The key strategy to combat growth in the infection rate is through "social distancing," maintaining physical separation from others. This strategy is incompatible with transit systems and ridership in nearly every transit market has plunged, causing agencies to reduce service levels to protect riders and employees. Still, mobility is required in many cities and the ability of cities to rapidly recover from widespread economic shutdown will require improving mobility systems in urban areas. In the past decade, more diverse shared mobility systems have proliferated, potentially improving the resilience and redundancy of the urban transportation system. Most recently, micromobility systems (i.e., bike share and scooter share) have entered cities and supplemented transportation systems in those areas. As a shared personal mobility vehicle, micromobility vehicles have been highly utilized in some markets in the early weeks of the pandemic even as transit ridership has declined. This is an important opportunity to understand how shared micromobility systems complement transit and can support social distancing to limit spread of disease while also facilitating urban transportation recovery. To that end, this study has two main aims. First, the research team will conduct a series of panel surveys for the duration of the pandemic of transit and micromobility users in two medium-sized transportation markets (Nashville and Portland) that have robust micromobility markets. These surveys will query and model mode choice behavior in relation to social distancing requirements, transit captivity, job status, income, activity restrictions, and others. The research team seeks to understand if riders self-regulate transit use and exposure and balance their behavior with perceived risks. The team will use detailed agency and micromobility operator data to track changes in ridership during recovery. The second aim is to project those findings on more aggregate ridership data of transit and micromobility across cities of different sizes and with different COVID-19 infection rates. This will provide detailed understanding of how riders react to pandemic in regard to two main shared modes; transit and micromobility systems. <br/><br/>To date there has been little work on the response of transit to disease outbreaks. The 2002/2003 SARS outbreak provides some aggregate evidence of long-duration drops in transit ridership. This work will provide important insight into disaggregate rider behavior, disease transmission, and personal- and community-risk tolerance. Moreover, this work will explore how emergent modes, like shared micromobility provide opportunities to maintain mobility while reducing close personal contact. Models developed can help predict how city transit systems will recover after a public health crisis. Public health emergencies will continue into the future and preparation on how to react to such emergencies will be important. For example, micromobility systems may provide much needed transportation services to supplement limited transit service. Understanding the dual roles of micromobility and transit will assist in limiting disease transmission and recovering the transportation system. Policy responses could be based on evidence generated in this study for the current and future infectious disease pandemics.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The COVID-19 pandemic has placed a burden on health care, the economy, transportation, and education around the world. Transit is among the main tools in fighting climate change, providing or improving accessibility, and addressing some equity issues. The strength and speed of ridership recovery after an outbreak are critical to the economic vitality of many urban areas. Previous cross-sectional studies have assessed the changes in public transportation ridership at specific points during the pandemic. However, little is known about the changes in risk perceptions and attitudes toward transportation during the extent of the pandemic. This study investigates the interactions between micromobility use, public transit use, and public perceptions of risk, decision making, and mode choice factors. To achieve this goal, we tracked a cohort of public transportation users longitudinally throughout the COVID-19 pandemic from May 2020 to October 2021 using 44-questions online surveys in 13 phases. The first phase surveys comprise a brief overview of the project and the consent form followed by four main sections: 1) travel behavior, 2) demographics, 3) health-related questions, and 4) open-ended questions. The surveys were distributed via e-mail to the e-mail list of two transit agencies, three micromobility companies, and one transit mobile application: Portland's TriMet, Nashville's WeGo, Bird, Spin, Lime, and Transit (formerly known as Transit App).  

We categorized participants into three panels: A) Nashville, TN and Portland, OR, both transit and micromobility users, started from May 2020, A+) Nashville, TN and Portland, OR, micromobility users, started from September 2020, and B) Nationwide, transit riders, started from November 2020. Respondents were surveyed approximately monthly during the early phase of the pandemic and bimonthly in later phases of the pandemic. In total, 4,378 participants started the first phases. Several criteria were applied to enhance data quality. Respondents who did not complete the entire survey were included in the study, leaving 1,606 responses in Nashville and Portland and 1,574 responses in the nationwide survey (330+ cities). In Panel A, 3% of participants (n=56) responded to all phases (11 surveys for Panel A), while 19% (n=320) responded to more than five phases of surveys. In Panel B, 5% of participants (n=72) responded to all phases (six surveys for Panel B), while 13% (n=197) responded to more than three phases of surveys.  

In general, about 74% of all respondents (n=2,484) were previously frequent transit riders (i.e., ride one or more days per week). However, the number of transit trips decreased for both groups during the pandemic, with changes following the number of cases? pattern. Similar patterns of changes in perceptions of risk and attitudes were observed over the course of this study.  Generally, the risk perception, ridership, and attitude towards transit use and health fluctuate with the changes in the number of cases, vaccination rates, and other factors related to the pandemic. Participants appear to show similar attitudes towards using public transportation and risk perception regardless of their prior-to-pandemic ridership frequency; however, new transit ridership distribution remained different between these two groups. The percentage of respondents who did not reduce transit differs across phases (from 15% to 56% across different panels and phases). In contrast, the percentage of respondents who replaced their transit trips with different modes does not change with a similar pattern. As expected, the chosen replacement modes and their frequency vary among panels. Respondents' age and gender impacts on ridership and perceptions vary in different locations and phases. With various individual and environmental factors, the dataset increases opportunities to discover more knowledge about public transportation during the pandemic.
